author: Staff reports
title: Friday night highlights: Week 9
text:
Close Image 1 of 2 Clear Creek wide receiver Landon Etzel (11) makes a gallant try but can't hang on to a pass while being defended by Clear Springs' Blake Tessitore in the first half of Friday night's District 24-6A game at CCISD Veterans Memorial Stadium. Clear Creek won 49-34. Clear Creek wide receiver Landon Etzel (11) makes a gallant try but can't hang on to a pass while being defended by Clear Springs' Blake Tessitore in the first half of Friday night's District 24-6A game at ... more Image 2 of 2 Clear Creek's Earnest Thomas (9) can't quite collar Clear Springs quarterback William McBride, who scores on a 15-yard run in the first half Friday night. Clear Creek's Earnest Thomas (9) can't quite collar Clear Springs quarterback William McBride, who scores on a 15-yard run in the first half Friday night. Photo: Thomas B. Shea Friday night highlights: Week 9 1 / 2 Back to Gallery 
Clear Creek and Clear Springs are separated by five miles along FM 518 in League City. That's helped fuel a rivalry - and give it a name that rolls nicely off the tongue. 
This season, the Fight for 518 went to Clear Creek, who moved to 8-0 with a 49-34 win Friday night. 
The Wildcats remain tied atop District 24-6A with Dickinson, which is also 8-0 and 5-0 in league play. 
Dickinson beat Friendswood 27-20, keeping the Mustangs tied with Clear Springs for third place. Both are 4-4 and 3-2 in district. 
Clear Creek jumped out to an early 14-0 lead before the Chargers could get in the end zone midway through the second quarter. Clear Creek answered with 23 seconds before the break however, taking a 21-6 lead into the break. 
The offenses went back and forth in the second half, but Clear Creek kept its lead to give the team its third straight win over the Chargers. 
Clear Springs leads the overall series 5-3. 
Clear Creek quarterback Chase Hildreth threw for 293 yards and two touchdowns. Da'Von Smith had 272 yards of offense and five scores. 

Mavericks shut down Tompkins 
A game that drew attention beyond the borders of Greater Houston quickly turned into nothing more than Morton Ranch taking it to Katy ISD's newest team. 
Morton Ranch forced a pair of turnovers early and never looked back, beating Tompkins 21-0 at Rhodes. 
Had Tompkins won, the Falcons, in just their second season, would have had the inside track to the fourth playoff spot in District 19-6A behind Katy, Cinco Ranch and Strake Jesuit. That would have sent Tompkins and Strake Jesuit to 6A's Division II bracket and Katy to Division I - where a possible finals matchup between three-time defending champion Allen had many across Texas salivating. 
But instead, Morton Ranch and Tompkins are 2-3 in district play behind those three and could be joined in a tie for fourth place by Seven Lakes (1-3), which plays winless Mayde Creek on Saturday. 
Morton Ranch's defense held Tompkins to 108 yards of total offense while collecting four sacks and forcing three turnovers. 
On offense, Dartaviouis Dixon ran for a score and threw for another. 

El Campo beats rival Bay City 
In one of the stats's oldest rivalries, El Campo extended its streak over Bay City, getting five rushing touchdowns from Kevin Dove in a 41-14 win. 
The rivalry is the oldest continuous series in the state, as the two met for the 96th consecutive year. In all, El Campo and Bay City have played 112 times. 
El Campo owns a 60-43-9 edge over the Blackcats. 
Darryl Florez (33-yard run) and La'Darrion Florez (95-yard kickoff return) scored Bay City's two scores. 

Dickinson player flown to hospital 
A Dickinson football player who was flown to a hospital for an injury suffered during a game Friday is doing OK, Dickinson coach John Snelson said late Friday. 
Snelson said linebacker Mitchell Butler suffered a neck injury in against Friendswood. Snelson said Butler was taken to the hospital for precautionary reasons. 

Pending rain changes schedule 
Mother Nature - or the threat of inclement weather - has shuffled nearly the entire Saturday schedule for the Houston area, which has gotten off lucky compared to its neighbors to the north. 
Week 9 games in the Dallas-Fort Worth area have been suspended, postponed and rescheduled since Thursday. As a result, some games were played Friday morning and afternoon as teams scrambled to find game officials. 
In Houston, every Saturday game except Barbers Hill and Humble has changed times or locations. The earliest two begin at 10 a.m. - Aldine Davis faces Eisenhower at Thorne in a first-place showdown and Katy takes on Strake Jesuit at Tully. 
Seven others kick off at 11 a.m.: Cypress Ranch-Cypress Falls (Berry Center), Langham Creek-Jersey Village (Pridgeon), Cinco Ranch-Seven Lakes (Rhodes), Bellaire-Sam Houston (Cowart), Milby-Chavez (Barnett), Westbury-Lamar (Delmar) and Sharpstown-Madison (Butler). 
Yates and Davis meet at 1 p.m. at Dyer, while Travis faces Elsik an hour later at Crump. At. 2:30 p.m., Washington and Wheatley meet at Barnett. 
As of Friday night, Barbers Hill and Humble were set for 6 p.m. on Saturday at Turner, but school officials could make a decision by the afternoon. 

Bearkats shock Klein Oak 
Klein upset Klein Oak 31-26 in a shootout Friday night. After a slow start, both teams exploded in the second quarter with five total touchdowns. The second half was a scoreless stalemate until the Klein pulled away with 10:21 left to play and held on despite a late comeback attempt from the Panthers. 
This Bearkats' win, along with Westfield defeating Dekaney and Montgomery falling to Klein Collins , tightens the race for the fourth seed in District 15-6A. Klein Oak had the edge, but finds itself in a three-way tie with Klein and Montgomery. 
Klein faces Dekaney next week, while Klein Oak and Montgomery will duke it out. 
From staff reports
